properties.Name: Thomas Eakins House
properties.descrip: The home and studio of renowned painter Thomas Eakins, this National Historic Landmark celebrates the life and work of one of America’s greatest realist artists.

properties.Name: Mural Arts Philadelphia
properties.descrip: The world’s largest public art program, transforming walls across the city into vibrant murals that reflect community voices and creativity.

properties.Name: Horwitz-Wasserman Holocaust Memorial Plaza
properties.descrip: Since 1964, Nathan Rapoport’s bronze *Monument to Six Million Jewish Martyrs* has stood on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway. Now part of the Horwitz-Wasserman Holocaust Memorial Plaza, it honors Holocaust victims and educates the public.

properties.Name: Academy of Music
properties.descrip: Opened in 1857, it is America’s oldest grand opera house still in use, hosting concerts, ballet, and major performing arts events.

properties.Name: PhilaGuernica
properties.descrip: The work is part of Mural Arts’ Rendering Justice project and was designed with help from the organization’s class at a recovery facility to show a positive message about Philadelphia’s youth culture.

properties.Name: Centre Square Building & “Clothespin” Sculpture
properties.descrip: A modern office complex famous for Claes Oldenburg’s 45-foot Clothespin sculpture, a symbol of Philadelphia’s commitment to public art.

properties.Name: Philadelphia Museum of Art
properties.descrip: One of the nation’s largest art museums, known for its world-class collections and the iconic “Rocky Steps.”

properties.Name: Walnut Street Theatre
properties.descrip: Founded in 1809, it is the oldest continuously operating theater in the United States and a hub for drama and musicals.

properties.Name: Rodin Museum
properties.descrip: Houses one of the most significant collections of Auguste Rodin’s sculptures outside Paris, set in a beautiful Beaux-Arts building and garden.
